contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bow" refers to the power of the army. Alternate translation: "the military power of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the bow of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my lovers" refers to Baal and other false gods, whom Israel has chosen to worship instead of Yahweh. The list of things are essential items that allow the people to live. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will go after my lovers, for they give me my bread and water, my wool and flax, my oil and drink

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably means that Israel's harvests and flocks will fail. Yahweh will remove his blessings from Israel, and the people will be left alone and in danger of attack. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will take back my wool and flax that were used to cover her nakedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: No one will try to help Israel. Here "hand" refers to God's power to punish. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: no one will rescue her out of my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will keep Israel's enemies away from them, there will be no more war, the people will be safe. Here "the bow, the sword, and the battle" represent war. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will drive away the bow, the sword, and the battle from the land, and I will make you lie down in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression refers to living in safety. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: lie down in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "David" represents all the descendants of David. Alternate translation: "a descendant of David to be their king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: David their king

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "trembling" represents feelings of awe and humility. Alternate translation: "they will come back to Yahweh and will humble themselves, honor him, and ask for his blessings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they will come trembling before Yahweh and his goodness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "honor" is a metonym that represents Yahweh, and "shame" is a metonym that represents idols. Alternate translation: "They have stopped worshiping me, their honorable God, and now worship shameful idols" or 2) some Bible versions translate this as "I will exchange their honor for shame." This means Yahweh will take away the things which the priests honor and cause the priests to be ashamed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: They exchanged their honor for shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) this refers to Adam, the first man or 2) this is a metonym that represents the people who live in a city in Israel called Adam. Alternate translation: "Like the people in the city of Adam" or 3) this refers to people in general. The word "Adam" means "man" or "humankind." Alternate translation: "Like all of humankind" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Like Adam

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Footprints of blood" probably represents the evildoers and their acts of murder. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Gilead is a city ... with footprints of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "prostitution" refers to Ephraim's worship of false gods. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Ephraim's prostitution

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "gray hairs" represent old age. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Gray hairs are sprinkled on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "tongue" refers to what the officials say. Alternate translation: "because they insult me" or "because they curse me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: because of the insolence of their tongues

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people worshiped an idol that looked like a calf, so Yahweh is speaking of their worship as if it were the calf itself. Alternate translation: "Because you worship your calf idol, your worship" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Your calf

contextId.occurrenceNote: Egypt and Memphis refer to the people who live there. Alternate translation: "the army of Egypt will capture you. You will die there, and the people in the city of Memphis will bury you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Egypt will gather them, and Memphis will bury them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "tents" represents the Israelites' homes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: their tents

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "children" are the people from that nation. Alternate translation: "but the people of Israel will bring out their children" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: but Ephraim will bring out his children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is stating that he will force Israel out of his land, the land of Canaan. Here "my house" represents Canaan. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will drive them out of my house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "guilt" is a metonym for the punishment that is associated with it. This punishment is spoken of as if it was a heavy load for them to carry. Alternate translation: "now is the time that Yahweh will punish them for their sins" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: now they must bear their guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Bethel" represents the people who live there. The prophet addresses the people of Bethel as if they were there listening to him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.glQuote: So it will happen to you, Bethel, because of your great wickedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents the enemies of Israel who will destroy Israel's cities. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The sword will fall on their cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gates offered security to city inhabitants from their enemies, and the bars secured the closed gates. To destroy the bars meant to take away the people's security. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: destroy the bars of their gates

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents God's will and decisions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: My heart has changed within me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" refers to the people who live there. This speaks of being loyal to God as "going about" with him. However, many versions have different interpretations of this difficult passage. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: But Judah is still going about with me

contextId.occurrenceNote: East winds were very hot and destructive to the land. Here it represents anything that is destructive. The people doing things that will destroy themselves is spoken of as if they are following the east wind. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: follows after the east wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh is threatening to force the people of Israel from their homes and make them live in tents. So, here to "live in tents" would represent being sent into exile, or 2) it is a promise that after their exile the people will live in tents again, and Yahweh will take care of them as he did when the Israelites left Egypt. So, here "to live in tents" would represent a return to an ideal situation when Yahweh took care of his people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will again make you live in tents

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "blood" refers to the guilt incurred by people who murder others. God will not forgive their sins. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: So his Lord will leave his blood on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Samaria" refers to the people in the city of Samaria who are guilty of rebelling against God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Samaria will be guilty, for she has rebelled against her God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" represents the enemy soldiers who used swords in battle. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: What a person says is called the fruit of his lips. Modern versions have different translations of this difficult passage. Alternate translation: "our words and songs of praise" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the fruit of our lips
